<https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/harrisob/F2CRY4F97/nodesdk_quick_start.mp4>

Short silent playback on the self contained docker images for quick start on the Node SDK

initial_comment.comment:
Short silent movie showing how using “readthedocs” to run a quick start self contained fabric environment based on three docker images running a sample node.js SDK application. 

some points to consider:
  — does not require cloning or downloading any fabric files
  — does not require vagrant
  — requires native docker (with docker compose)

text:
<@U12452RAP> Kai, I added the following explanation to the PR comment in response to your question:

The main reason to remove typescript is to simplify the tool chain in the contributor's development environment. the original motivation for using TypeScript on the node.js SDK project revolved around it's affordance for code structure constructs such as interfaces and classes. while that can be easily achieved with much simpler prototype based javascript techniques as demonstrated in base.js. along with CommonJS modules we can have the equivalence of interfaces and classes rather easily.

for strong typing, I don't think it's a big problem really. I've been on large projects completely based on node.js (one of them made up of 10+ separate microservices projects) and enforcing types using documentation and communication is more than enough. relying on unit tests to enforce types is a much better mechanism.

hope this helps.

<@U0Z81GL6S> <@U0MRPSV45> <@U1KFBBWG1> <@U1L2C9F3R> <@U0KQ9QKH6> <@U1AU8DRQR> I populated the Sprint 2 board with incomplete work items from Sprint 1. can you please review to make sure the status is accurate. especially, if an item is complete, mark them “Done”. thanks. <https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=41>
